text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA | SEPTEMBER 2020
label: BODY

text: CASE EXCERPT
label: BODY

text: OCHA launched the Humanitarian Data Exchange (HDX) in 2014 with the goal of making data easy to find and use
label: BODY

text: for analysis. HDX has been able to scale and secure funding in ways that other technology-focused innovations in
label: BODY

text: the humanitarian sector have not. When HDX was launched in 2014, it held almost 900 datasets. By early 2020, that
label: BODY

text: number had skyrocketed to over 17,000. The data covers every active humanitarian crisis, from Afghanistan to Yemen,
label: BODY

text: and has been shared by hundreds of organizations, from ACLED to WFP. This case study illustrates the decisions and
label: BODY

text: key results of the past six years that have informed the direction of the platform and contributed to its success.
label: BODY

text: CASE STUDY
label: HH1

text: THE HUMANITARIAN DATA EXCHANGE:
label: BODY

text: CRITICAL DECISIONS, KEY RESULTS AND THE ROAD AHEAD
label: BODY

text: SEPTEMBER 2020
label: BODY

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA | SEPTEMBER 2020
label: BODY

text: TABLE OF CONTENTS
label: H4

label: H4

text: ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS
label: BODY

text: This case study was produced by the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA)
label: BODY

text: Centre for Humanitarian Data in The Hague, which manages the HDX platform. The study was written by Sarah
label: BODY

text: Telford with contributions from Stuart Campo, CJ Hendrix, Simon Johnson, David Megginson and and Niall Saville.
label: BODY

text: Graphic design is by Yumi Endo and Lena Kim. This work was made possible with funding from the Institute of
label: BODY

text: Development Studies in partnership with the UK’s Department for International Development (now the Foreign,
label: BODY

text: Commonwealth & Development Office). For additional information, contact the Centre for Humanitarian Data at
label: BODY

text: centrehumdata@un.org.
label: BODY

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA | SEPTEMBER 2020
label: BODY

text: The Humanitarian Data Exchange (HDX) is an open platform for sharing data across
label: BODY

text: crises and organizations. Launched by the United Nations Office for the Coordination
label: BODY

text: of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) in July 2014, the goal of HDX is to make humanitarian
label: BODY

text: data easy to find and use for analysis. Today, the data covers every active humanitarian
label: BODY

text: crisis, from Afghanistan to Yemen. In 2019, HDX was accessed by over 600,000 people
label: BODY

text: from almost every country in the world.
label: BODY

text: The search for data related to the COVID-19 pandemic caused a spike in users unlike
label: BODY

text: any other crisis covered by HDX: almost 400,000 people visited the site in March and
label: BODY

text: April alone, with 2020 on track to be a record-setting year across all metrics.
label: BODY

text: 1.  INTRODUCTION
label: H4

text: Hundreds of organizations have contributed to HDX, from the Armed Conflict Location
label: BODY

text: & Event Data Project (ACLED) to the United Nations World Food Programme (WFP).
label: BODY

text: The many partners sharing data have proven the value of collective action in a
label: BODY

text: humanitarian sector that relies on cooperation. Making data available in one place has
label: BODY

text: undoubtedly created efficiency in the system: humanitarians, donors, academics, and
label: BODY

text: journalists no longer need to chase personal contacts to locate data. Instead, they can
label: BODY

text: go to HDX and search for it. If the data is not there, we will work with partners to find it
label: BODY

text: and ensure it is shared on HDX so that everyone can use it.
label: BODY

text: The HDX team includes OCHA staff and consultants who are based in North America,
label: BODY

text: Europe, Africa and Asia. HDX is managed by OCHA’s Centre for Humanitarian Data,
label: BODY

text: which is located in The Hague. OCHA is part of the United Nations Secretariat and is
label: BODY

text: responsible for bringing together humanitarian actors to ensure a coherent response to
label: BODY

text: emergencies.
label: BODY

text: As HDX marked its sixth anniversary in July 2020, we thought it would be useful to
label: BODY

text: reflect on the key decisions that we have made along the way, both as a reminder
label: BODY

text: to ourselves and as an example for our partners and stakeholders. There is little
label: BODY

text: documentation on the process of innovation in the humanitarian sector, and we
label: BODY

text: hope that our case study might contribute to this literature so that together we can
label: BODY

text: understand the promise and potential pitfalls of introducing change into our work.
label: BODY

text: Even as innovations like HDX become established services, they require continued
label: BODY

text: investment to truly scale and deliver on long-term goals, an even greater challenge in a
label: BODY

text: humanitarian system that is not self-sustaining and relies on variable donor funding.
label: BODY

text: Homepage of HDX in August 2020
label: BODY

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA | SEPTEMBER 2020
label: BODY

text: We have organized the case study into the following sections: Key Learnings; Making
label: BODY

text: the Case; the Humanitarian Innovation Context; Building HDX; HDX Today; and the
label: BODY

text: Road Ahead.
label: BODY

text: There are many challenges with creating and sustaining something new within an
label: BODY

text: organization and a system. Below is a list of our key learnings from working within
label: BODY

text: the United Nations on a global product innovation. We understand that these may or
label: BODY

text: may not be transferable to different organizations and cultures, or to those working on
label: BODY

text: non-technical innovations.
label: BODY

text: •	 Seek external funding. Although innovation teams may be able to access funds
label: BODY

text: through their organization’s annual budget process, applying for external funds
label: BODY

text: requires a clear articulation of the problem and solution, and invites constructive
label: BODY

text: criticism of the approach being considered. We received initial project funding from
label: BODY

text: the United Kingdom, Sweden and the Humanitarian Innovation Fund.
label: BODY

text: •	 Find a senior-level champion. You are going to need help. Having a senior
label: BODY

text: champion within your organization to clear a pathway for your ideas and advocate
label: BODY

text: for your work with the management team is essential. Our senior champion was Ms.
label: BODY

text: Gwi-Yeop Son who was, at the time, Director of the Corporate Programmes Division at
label: BODY

text: OCHA.
label: BODY

text: •	 Bring in influential partners early. Consider who your early adopters should be
label: BODY

text: and engage them directly so that they feel included in the process and can help
label: BODY

text: create a solution that meets their needs. Once they are onboard, thank them
label: BODY

text: publicly for their contribution. WFP was the first large United Nations agency to
label: BODY

text: share their data on HDX.
label: BODY

text: •	 Use an agile development process and open source software. As the saying
label: BODY

text: goes in relation to technology development, release early and often. Even if the
label: BODY

text: product isn’t exactly where you think it should be, share it publicly (with caveats)
label: BODY

text: and respond to user feedback quickly. Relying on an open source framework saves
label: BODY

text: development time and ensures you are not dependent on a custom solution or
label: BODY

text: tied to licensing fees. HDX was built using CKAN, an open source, free software for
label: BODY

text: publishing data. Our code is available on GitHub.
label: BODY

text: •	 Be user-driven. Any technical tool is likely to cost millions of dollars to develop and
label: BODY

text: maintain over its lifetime. Investing in user research upfront and continuing to be
label: BODY

text: guided by user feedback lowers the risk of failure and can actually save money. We
label: BODY

text: partnered with frog design to conduct extensive user research in early 2014 and have
label: BODY

text: re-engaged them and other firms as we considered major feature improvements.
label: BODY

text: •	 A network or distributed model allows for scale. ‘But does it scale?’ is a good
label: BODY

text: question to keep asking yourself as you establish processes and systems for a tool
label: BODY

text: or platform. HDX was designed to allow approved organizations to share data from
label: BODY

text: anywhere in the world, simultaneously making it accessible to everyone in the world.
label: BODY

text: •	 Put trust front and center with any work on data. Trust powers the data
label: BODY

text: economy in the humanitarian sector. Without it, data is not shared. Build and
label: BODY

text: maintain trust between organizations by ensuring, to the extent possible, that data
label: BODY

text: is used for the purpose that was originally intended and that data does not end up
label: BODY

text: in the wrong hands. We took time to develop the HDX Terms of Service and a quality
label: BODY

text: assurance process for data shared on HDX.
label: BODY

text: •	 Stay focused on your core. As any technology gains traction, it is tempting to think
label: BODY

text: of new features to add or new things to build. Instead ‘stick to your knitting’ and get
label: BODY

text: better at what you are already good at. Do the right thing, do it well, and do a lot of
label: BODY

text: 2.  KEY LEARNINGS
label: H4

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA | SEPTEMBER 2020
label: BODY

text: it. The core focus of HDX is data sharing, rather than data analysis or data
label: BODY

text: visualization.
label: BODY

text: •	 Have a geographically distributed team. It goes without saying that diversity in
label: BODY

text: skills and culture is good for creativity and problem solving within a team. Having
label: BODY

text: personnel in field locations also helps to build local relationships around data
label: BODY

text: sharing. HDX established its first field team in Nairobi in 2014, with support from The
label: BODY

text: Rockefeller Foundation, and subsequently established teams in Dakar in 2016, with
label: BODY

text: support from the Paul Allen Foundation, and in Jakarta in 2018 in partnership with
label: BODY

text: UN Global Pulse.
label: BODY

text: •	 Measure things that matter. Consider what success looks like and figure out a way
label: BODY

text: to measure it. Be transparent about your goals by sharing your results framework
label: BODY

text: publicly. Signal your ambition and ask for help in getting there. We established an
label: BODY

text: objectives and key results framework in 2015 and review our results quarterly.
label: BODY

text: •	 Communicate regularly and create a community. The saying ‘build it and they
label: BODY

text: will come’ is not true. You need to create pathways for people to join the adventure
label: BODY

text: through blogs, videos, and events with a clear call to action. Learn to translate
label: BODY

text: technical jargon into language that everyone can understand. We created a blog
label: BODY

text: and Twitter account in 2013 and have consistently produced content since then.
label: BODY

text: In late 2013, a team within OCHA1 started work on a data initiative with the goal of
label: BODY

text: making it easy to find and use humanitarian data from different sources and across
label: BODY

text: crises.
label: BODY

text: 3.  MAKING THE
label: H4

text: CASE
label: H4

text: The main challenge we were trying to address was that humanitarian data was hard to
label: BODY

text: find, and once found, it wasn’t clear if it could be trusted or re-used: Was it the latest
label: BODY

text: version? Was there any metadata about the source and data collection methodology?
label: BODY

text: Was there a license attached to it? Getting access to data, and answers to questions,
label: BODY

text: depended to a large extent on personal connections.
label: BODY

text: One-off data websites or shared drives might be created for a specific humanitarian
label: BODY

text: crisis, but when the crisis ended they would stop being maintained, resulting in what
label: BODY

text: was known as a data graveyard. We observed from working on previous emergencies
label: BODY

text: that data sites were easy to set up but difficult to maintain. This led to a sense of
label: BODY

text: frustration among those working in and reporting on humanitarian crises, who
label: BODY

text: would invest effort in working with a new data initiative or online tool, only to see it
label: BODY

text: abandoned.
label: BODY

text: Seeing an opportunity for improvement, we began to research options and approaches
label: BODY

text: for managing data and making it openly accessible. Our main inspiration came from
label: BODY

text: the World Bank’s open data initiative, which provided free and open access to global
label: BODY

text: development data. In 2012, the World Bank launched a website where anyone could
label: BODY

text: access data that had previously been behind a paywall (and from which they had
label: BODY

text: generated significant income). World Bank colleagues shared their knowledge about
label: BODY

text: open data frameworks and policies, and offered pointers on navigating resistance to
label: BODY

text: open data within organizations and governments.
label: BODY

text: 1  The initial team included
label: BODY

text: Sarah Telford, CJ Hendrix,
label: BODY

text: David Megginson, and Luis
label: BODY

text: Capelo with strategic advice
label: BODY

text: from Richard Tyson and
label: BODY

text: technical advice from Aidan
label: BODY

text: McGuire.
label: BODY

text: OCHA has always played an important and unique role with information
label: BODY

text: management, in line with its coordination mandate. OCHA’s data work is mainly
label: BODY

text: focused on aggregation: while UN and NGO partners collect sector-specific
label: BODY

text: data, such as data on shelter requirements or food insecurity, OCHA is tasked
label: BODY

text: with bringing this data together to create a common operational picture of a
label: BODY

text: humanitarian response.
label: BODY

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA | SEPTEMBER 2020
label: BODY

text: As we became clear about what we wanted to create, we began to make the case to
label: BODY

text: management for capacity and resources. We worked with a senior-level champion,
label: BODY

text: Gwi-Yeop Son, at the time the Director of OCHA’s Corporate Programmes Division,
label: BODY

text: who helped us to navigate the bureaucracy and get leadership attention. This would
label: BODY

text: become a critical alliance for the creation of HDX and also for establishing the Centre
label: BODY

text: for Humanitarian Data years later.
label: BODY

text: Our first task was to prove that we were not duplicating ongoing efforts within OCHA.
label: BODY

text: We consulted with different headquarters sections to see if they were working on
label: BODY

text: a global solution, only to be told that they had not seen it as their responsibility.
label: BODY

text: Information technology colleagues felt it was something the business side should lead
label: BODY

text: on, while the business side did not have the technical knowledge to do it.
label: BODY

text: We also needed evidence to show there was demand for the solution we were
label: BODY

text: proposing. In October 2013, we ran a survey on ReliefWeb to understand the data
label: BODY

text: needs and perceptions of the humanitarian community. Almost 3,500 people
label: BODY

text: responded, with the majority based in Africa and working for an NGO. The survey found
label: BODY

text: that ReliefWeb users regularly did analysis with humanitarian data, but the data was
label: BODY

text: hard to find, difficult to compare and not always trustworthy or timely.
label: BODY

text: Although OCHA management became supportive of the idea, we were asked to raise
label: BODY

text: new funds to cover the work. The United Kingdom’s Department for International
label: BODY

text: Development (DFID) Humanitarian Innovation and Evidence Programme was the
label: BODY

text: first to commit funds, followed by the Government of Sweden and the Humanitarian
label: BODY

text: Innovation Fund (HIF). Although time-consuming, applying for innovation funding
label: BODY

text: allowed us to refine our ideas and get constructive feedback.
label: BODY

text: Altogether, we raised approximately $1.7 million by late 2013. HDX was publicly
label: BODY

text: launched in July 2014 at the Open Knowledge Festival in Berlin.
label: BODY

text: 4.  THE
label: HH2

text: HUMANITARIAN
label: H4

text: INNOVATION
label: H4

text: CONTEXT
label: H4

text: This is the opening paragraph of a report from the Active Learning Network for
label: BODY

text: Accountability and Performance (ALNAP) and the HIF titled ‘More than just luck:
label: BODY

text: innovation in humanitarian action’.2 Published in 2016, it provides a useful framework
label: BODY

text: for understanding the state of innovation in the sector and the context within which
label: BODY

text: HDX was created.
label: BODY

text: The concept behind HDX — open data aggregation — was not a new idea. For this
label: BODY

text: reason, we did not initially think of it as an innovation but simply as a service that
label: BODY

text: OCHA should be providing. With the management directive to seek external funding,
label: BODY

text: we discovered that new project funding would need to come from donor funds that
label: BODY

text: were set aside for innovation, given the higher risk of failure and an uncertain outcome.
label: BODY

text: Through this exploration, we came to understand HDX as an ‘adaptation-driven
label: BODY

text: innovation’ where the approach existed elsewhere but was new to the humanitarian
label: BODY

text: sector.
label: BODY

text: 2  Obrecht, A. and T. Warner,
label: BODY

text: A. (2016) ‘More than just luck:
label: BODY

text: Innovation in humanitarian
label: BODY

text: action’. HIF/ALNAP Study.
label: BODY

text: London: ALNAP/ODI.
label: BODY

text: “The humanitarian system has a proven ability to produce innovations, but
label: BODY

text: it does so sporadically and often struggles to take good ideas to scale quickly.
label: BODY

text: The system does not consistently invest in innovation, and humanitarian
label: BODY

text: actors have not always been successful at actively managing innovation
label: BODY

text: processes. Due to this, the number of landmark innovations that have been
label: BODY

text: integrated into the system has been frustratingly low and understanding of
label: BODY

text: best practices for humanitarian innovation remains limited.”
label: BODY

text: Data is considered to
label: BODY

text: be ‘open’ if anyone can
label: BODY

text: freely access, use, re-use
label: BODY

text: and redistribute it, for
label: BODY

text: any purpose, without
label: BODY

text: restrictions. People
label: BODY

text: should be able to directly
label: BODY

text: download the data in
label: BODY

text: common formats or
label: BODY

text: through software that can
label: BODY

text: read the data remotely.
label: BODY

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA | SEPTEMBER 2020
label: BODY

text: As part of a strategy that prioritized innovation as a key area of investment, DFID
label: BODY

text: established the Humanitarian Innovation and Evidence Programme in 2012 with a
label: BODY

text: multi-year £48 million budget aimed at improving research and development activities
label: BODY

text: in the humanitarian system. The UK was also one of the main donors, along with the
label: BODY

text: Netherlands and Sweden, for ELHRA’s Humanitarian Innovation Fund, which was
label: BODY

text: created in 2010.
label: BODY

text: Our engagement with the innovation experts at these two initiatives shaped our
label: BODY

text: approach and their seed funding created permission for other donors and partners
label: BODY

text: to support us. On the strong advice of DFID, we established an independent
label: BODY

text: advisory board for the first year of the project. The board met regularly and included
label: BODY

text: representatives from Flowminder, Google, Tufts University, WFP and the World Bank.
label: BODY

text: This outside expertise proved invaluable as we navigated challenging issues such as
label: BODY

text: data licensing, drafting the HDX Terms of Service, and gaining early adopters.
label: BODY

text: HDX is a product innovation, one of the 4 Ps in the classic innovation model. But for
label: BODY

text: HDX to be successful, it would involve a process innovation, one that would shift data
label: BODY

text: sharing from a centralized, hub-and-spoke model to a decentralized, network model.
label: BODY

text: 4.1 Innovation Process
label: H4

text: Timeline
label: BODY

text: Although HDX had gained traction by 2015, we had spent the initial innovation funds
label: BODY

text: and needed to find a regular funding source. OCHA agreed to move the cost of HDX into
label: BODY

text: its annual programme budget, which we took as a sign of success, but the relief was
label: BODY

text: short-lived. Soon thereafter, OCHA went through a severe downward cycle of its budget
label: BODY

text: with consequences for staff roles and existing services. We knew that putting the brakes
label: BODY

text: on our development work at this early stage might cause HDX to fail.
label: BODY

text: 3  The dominant model for
label: BODY

text: understanding the ‘what’ of
label: BODY

text: innovation is based on the
label: BODY

text: classic ‘4 Ps’ model outlined by
label: BODY

text: Dave Francis and John
label: BODY

text: Bessant (2005). The wording
label: BODY

text: used here is taken from
label: BODY

text: ALNAP.
label: BODY

text: The continuum from programming to innovation (ALNAP/HIF).
label: BODY

text: The 4 Ps of Innovation3
label: BODY

text: changes in the things (products/services) an organization offers.
label: BODY

text: changes in the ways products and services are created or delivered.
label: BODY

text: changes in the context in which the products/services are framed and communicated.
label: BODY

text: changes in the underlying mental models that shape the organization does.
label: BODY

text: roduct Innovation
label: BODY

text: rocess Innovation
label: BODY

text: osition Innovation
label: BODY

text: aradigm Innovation
label: BODY

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA | SEPTEMBER 2020
label: BODY

text: It was this pressure that led us to begin conversations with the Netherlands Ministry
label: BODY

text: of Foreign Affairs about creating something more ambitious, along the lines of a
label: BODY

text: position or paradigm innovation, that would encompass HDX but also take on the wider
label: BODY

text: challenges of data policy and data literacy. These ideas coincided with the holding of
label: BODY

text: the World Humanitarian Summit in May 2016, which had a strong focus on achieving
label: BODY

text: transformational change.
label: BODY

text: OCHA launched the Centre for Humanitarian Data in The Hague in 2017 with the aim
label: BODY

text: of increasing the use and impact of data in the humanitarian sector. The work is an
label: BODY

text: extension of HDX’s goal of making it easy to find and use data for analysis. HDX was able
label: BODY

text: to scale because it became part of the Centre with a multi-year investment from the
label: BODY

text: Netherlands.
label: BODY

text: 4  The HIF has developed a five-
label: BODY

text: stage model for the innovation
label: BODY

text: process which we can use to
label: BODY

text: understand HDX’s progress.
label: BODY

text: 5  Wilson, Mark, “How the Candy
label: BODY

text: Crush of Data is Saving Lives
label: BODY

text: in Nepal” (30 April 2015), Fast
label: BODY

text: Company.
label: BODY

text: HDX Innovation Process Timeline
label: BODY

text: RECOGNITION OF THE CHALLENGE
label: BODY

text: IDEATION OF THE SOLUTION
label: BODY

text: DEVELOPMENT OF THE INNOVATION
label: BODY

text: IMPLEMENTATION OF THE INNOVATION
label: BODY

text: DIFFUSION OF SUCCESSFUL INNOVATION
label: BODY

text: and before
label: BODY

text: 2014 and
label: BODY

text: Data about humanitarian crises was hard to
label: BODY

text: find, and when found, it was out of date or the
label: BODY

text: origin was unknown, making it hard to trust.
label: BODY

text: Humanitarians seeking data relied heavily on
label: BODY

text: individual relationships and emailed requests
label: BODY

text: for data access.
label: BODY

text: Learning from the experience of the World
label: BODY

text: Bank’s open data initiative, we explored
label: BODY

text: technical options for open data aggregation
label: BODY

text: and consulted within OCHA about existing
label: BODY

text: internal efforts and appetite for a new
label: BODY

text: approach.
label: BODY

text: With initial funding from the UK, Sweden and
label: BODY

text: the HIF, we began to build HDX. After six months
label: BODY

text: of user research and technical development, we
label: BODY

text: launched the beta version of HDX in July 2014
label: BODY

text: at the Open Knowledge Festival event in Berlin.
label: BODY

text: HDX is used to share data for the West Africa
label: BODY

text: Ebola Outbreak in September 2014 and gained
label: BODY

text: traction with key organizations. Our first crisis
label: BODY

text: page is  developed and launched.
label: BODY

text: We strengthened our position as a useful
label: BODY

text: shared resource during the Nepal Earthquake
label: BODY

text: in 2015.5 HDX is included as a finalist in Fast
label: BODY

text: Company’s Innovation by Design Award in the
label: BODY

text: social good category in 2015.
label: BODY

text: The World Humanitarian Summit is held in
label: BODY

text: Istanbul in May 2016 with innovation as one of
label: BODY

text: the key areas of focus. OCHA and the Netherlands
label: BODY

text: agree to establish the Centre for Humanitarian
label: BODY

text: Data in The Hague, which will manage HDX under
label: BODY

text: a new business model that allows for continued
label: BODY

text: investment in the platform.
label: BODY

text: HDX is established as the first place to go to
label: BODY

text: find humanitarian data across crises. Use of
label: BODY

text: HDX grows from 20,000 unique users a month
label: BODY

text: (based on three month rolling average) in July
label: BODY

text: 2017 to 94,000 unique users a month by July
label: BODY

text: 2020. The number of datasets grows from 900
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA | SEPTEMBER 2020
label: BODY

text: 5.  BUILDING HDX:
label: H4

text: EARLY DECISIONS
label: H4

text: As we built HDX, we faced a number of critical decisions that shaped what it would
label: BODY

text: become. We knew we were not assured of success and were often reminded of the
label: BODY

text: adage that over half of all technology projects fail.
label: BODY

text: One of our first decisions was around the technology we would use to manage the
label: BODY

text: platform. We had two use cases: we wanted partners to be able to share their data
label: BODY

text: about a crisis (e.g., a single dataset with the results of a needs assessment in Sudan)
label: BODY

text: and we wanted to create a database to compare data across sources and crises. We
label: BODY

text: referred to the latter as the Common Humanitarian Dataset, which would include
label: BODY

text: indicators by country, such as the number of people in need of assistance or the
label: BODY

text: number of displaced people.
label: BODY

text: Curation Process Software
label: BODY

text: In late 2013, the Government of Luxembourg funded a programmer at their technology
label: BODY

text: partner Hitec to help us build a prototype system for managing the Common
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian Dataset. We referred to this as the Curation Process Software (CPS). The
label: BODY

text: system would pull data from selected sources, standardize it, and make it available via
label: BODY

text: an application programming interface (API) for other systems to access.
label: BODY

text: Getting data from existing sources mostly consisted of ‘scraping’ data out of web pages
label: BODY

text: (such as WHO’s Global Health Observatory). We used the ScraperWiki platform for data
label: BODY

text: extraction, and CPS for standardizing, storing, and serving the resulting data. APIs,
label: BODY

text: which are more robust ways of automated data sharing, were then much less common
label: BODY

text: among humanitarian data providers.
label: BODY

text: CKAN
label: BODY

text: Simultaneously, we were exploring options for a platform to expose the data from
label: BODY

text: partners and from CPS, allowing users to search for the data they needed in a single
label: BODY

text: place. For this, we decided on CKAN, open source software for data publishing from
label: BODY

text: the Open Knowledge Foundation. Choosing an existing platform came with some
label: BODY

text: limitations, but it freed our technical team from developing and maintaining a custom
label: BODY

text: solution. Instead, the team focused on extending CKAN and building other tools to help
label: BODY

text: expand and maintain HDX’s data ecosystem.
label: BODY

text: The choice to use CKAN also allowed us to move rapidly from the start of development
label: BODY

text: in March 2014 to a public launch in July, which gave the project momentum at a critical
label: BODY

text: time. CKAN still serves as the core platform for HDX.
label: BODY

text: The CPS system provided close to 900 datasets to help ‘bootstrap’ HDX for the July 2014
label: BODY

text: launch. However the experience of maintaining that approach made the HDX team
label: BODY

text: question the feasibility of scaling CPS to include significant amounts of subnational
label: BODY

text: data. Additionally, monitoring the use of HDX made it clear that users were not very
label: BODY

text: interested in national level statistics, which could be several years out of date.
label: BODY

text: In 2015, the HDX team decided to retire CPS in favour of focusing on direct data sharing
label: BODY

text: by organizations. We also focused on the Humanitarian Exchange Language (HXL) as a
label: BODY

text: longer-term, more sustainable approach to standardizing humanitarian data (see box
label: BODY

text: on page 13).
label: BODY

text: 5.1 Build, Buy or
label: H4

text: Open Source?
label: BODY

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA | SEPTEMBER 2020
label: BODY

text: The most consequential decision we made was to invest a significant portion of our
label: BODY

text: first year budget on user research. For this, we found inspiration from UNICEF’s Office
label: BODY

text: of Innovation, which was ahead of its time in using design and technology to improve
label: BODY

text: the lives of children around the world. It was through our conversations with colleagues
label: BODY

text: at UNICEF that we came to understand the value of user research and the work they
label: BODY

text: had done with frog, a global design firm.
label: BODY

text: We started working with frog in April 2014 in order to bring user needs to the center of
label: BODY

text: the HDX design process. Given that there had been a number of platforms, websites,
label: BODY

text: and tools introduced to humanitarians over the years—many of which were later
label: BODY

text: abandoned—we knew that there would be some scepticism and fatigue in adopting yet
label: BODY

text: another solution. We wanted to hear directly from OCHA staff and partners on some of
label: BODY

text: their pain points and what would help make their data-related work easier. We believed
label: BODY

text: that we would only be able to encourage a new set of behaviours around data sharing
label: BODY

text: and gain adoption by offering a compelling user experience.
label: BODY

text: Over 14 weeks, we worked with the frog team to define the needs of the data
label: BODY

text: producers and consumers, and conceptualize the user interfaces for data sharing and
label: BODY

text: use. The team took part in over one hundred interviews with partner organizations,
label: BODY

text: stakeholders, governments, and within OCHA. They conducted field research in Nairobi,
label: BODY

text: Kenya and in Bogota, Colombia.
label: BODY

text: 5.2 Investing in
label: H4

text: User Research
label: BODY

text: Card sorting activities as part of the design research with frog and partners
label: BODY

text: in Bogota, Nairobi and New York in 2014.
label: BODY

text: The main research insights included the following:
label: BODY

text: •	 Elevate people and promote collaboration: Personal relationships are
label: BODY

text: foundational to humanitarian work and data access is often reliant upon the level
label: BODY

text: of trust attributed to an individual or organization.
label: BODY

text: •	 Tell the data’s story: Humanitarians are looking for data context and insight in
label: BODY

text: order to understand the information and use it appropriately.
label: BODY

text: •	 Demonstrate the value of making data accessible: Information is predominately
label: BODY

text: shared in the form of documents. Disaggregated data is needed for analysis and
label: BODY

text: effective coordination, yet it is rarely shared.
label: BODY

text: •	 Promote data services, not just data and tools: Data needs vary significantly
label: BODY

text: across regions and organizations. Personalized services will drive adoption and
label: BODY

text: growth of the platform.
label: BODY

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA | SEPTEMBER 2020
label: BODY

text: The research team also established the design language for HDX that we are still using
label: BODY

text: today. To inform this, they asked interviewees what words they would like to associate
label: BODY

text: with the new platform. We were told that it should be practical, friendly, social, trusted
label: BODY

text: and strategic. The design team went to work to develop the homepage, dataset pages
label: BODY

text: and other key pages along the user journey. The aim was to not just create a ‘minimum
label: BODY

text: viable product’ but what frog referred to as a ‘minimum loveable product’. In parallel,
label: BODY

text: the technical team at frog helped us to define the sites’ information architecture, key
label: BODY

text: pages, users flows, and common layouts.
label: BODY

text: As we launched HDX in Berlin in July 2014, the Ebola outbreak in West Africa was
label: BODY

text: intensifying. By late August, the United Nations Mission for the Ebola Emergency
label: BODY

text: Response contacted us to see if they could use HDX as the platform of record for their
label: BODY

text: Ebola-related data. We understood that there was a significant responsibility in taking
label: BODY

text: on this role and that the site was still untested. Nevertheless, we agreed to support the
label: BODY

text: mission and the Ebola response became our top priority.
label: BODY

text: At the time, WHO was publishing daily situation reports in PDF format, which included
label: BODY

text: a table for the Ebola cases and deaths in affected countries. Unfortunately, the PDF
label: BODY

text: format meant that researchers and organizations could not easily incorporate the data
label: BODY

text: into their own spreadsheets or databases. The HDX data team started to manually
label: BODY

text: extract the data from these reports and add the figures to a machine-readable file that
label: BODY

text: was shared on HDX with WHO as the source.
label: BODY

text: The Ebola cases and deaths data became the most popular dataset on the platform
label: BODY

text: and quickly proved the value of open data as well as the need for a service to transform
label: BODY

text: raw data into something more accessible. The New York Times used the data to create a
label: BODY

text: visual that ran on their homepage and reached millions of readers.
label: BODY

text: Ebola Crisis Page
label: BODY

text: More partners began to share their Ebola-related datasets on HDX, covering everything
label: BODY

text: from the location of treatment centres to the location of rivers and roads. To help
label: BODY

text: non-technical users see what was inside the data files, we created our first crisis page
label: BODY

text: which included a choropleth map of cases and deaths in Liberia, Guinea and Sierra
label: BODY

text: Leone and a chart showing the trend in cases and deaths over time. This further
label: BODY

text: incentivized data sharing and raised the profile of HDX’s capabilities during a significant
label: BODY

text: crisis.
label: BODY

text: 5.3 Offering Data Services
label: H4

text: The West Africa Ebola Outbreak Crisis Page
label: BODY

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA | SEPTEMBER 2020
label: BODY

text: WFP Organization Page
label: BODY

text: Around the same time, WFP became the first large UN agency to publish data on HDX.
label: BODY

text: They started by sharing their food market price data for Ebola-affected countries in
label: BODY

text: West Africa, then expanded this to include subnational food prices data for over 2,100
label: BODY

text: markets in around 100 countries. In exchange, we offered to create a custom data visual
label: BODY

text: showing food prices for commodities in each country.
label: BODY

text: We tracked the downloads of WFP’s data and the results showed that more people were
label: BODY

text: accessing their data through HDX than through WFP’s own website. WFP referred to this
label: BODY

text: as the ‘HDX advantage’: if your organization’s goal is for more people to use your data,
label: BODY

text: then share it via HDX. We then created the first custom organization page on HDX to
label: BODY

text: showcase the data and visual, using WFP’s brand identity.
label: BODY

text: The WFP Organization Page
label: BODY

text: The early lesson that we drew from the Ebola response and collaboration with WFP was
label: BODY

text: that we needed to provide ‘high touch’ data services for HDX to gain adoption. We did
label: BODY

text: not want to take data without offering something in return, which ultimately created
label: BODY

text: a strong community in support of our goal. Anyone could add a data file to a website,
label: BODY

text: but to make that data usable for analysis, it would need more work, whether that was
label: BODY

text: through data cleaning, data processing or visualization.
label: BODY

text: To ensure we had trusted partnerships with field-based organizations, we located
label: BODY

text: teams in two OCHA Regional Offices. The Rockefeller Foundation provided a
label: BODY

text: grant to establish a three-person team in Nairobi in late 2014, and the Paul Allen
label: BODY

text: Foundation provided a grant to establish a three-person team in Dakar in 2016. We
label: BODY

text: began to see national and regional organizations coming onto the platform, and
label: BODY

text: our teams were able to provide direct data services in support of humanitarian
label: BODY

text: operations. These field teams remain in place today with the addition of a data
label: BODY

text: manager in Jakarta who is co-located in the UN Global Pulse office.
label: BODY

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA | SEPTEMBER 2020
label: BODY

text: As HDX gained more users and data, we began to think of ways to improve and extend
label: BODY

text: the platform. This is a risky period for any project, where it can be easy to lose focus
label: BODY

text: and squander resources. Fortunately, around that time, a World Bank colleague wisely
label: BODY

text: advised us to ‘stick to your knitting’— to get better at what we were already good at,
label: BODY

text: instead of expanding the scope of HDX.
label: BODY

text: We have tried to follow that advice. For example, there are many good options for data
label: BODY

text: visualization software, so there was little point in turning HDX into an open source
label: BODY

text: version of Microsoft Power BI or Tableau. However, we have always wanted to help
label: BODY

text: users find insight from data. For this, we created two features — Geo-Preview and Quick
label: BODY

text: Charts — that automatically convert data in files into charts and maps that present
label: BODY

text: on the dataset page. We believe this functionality increases the ‘speed to insight’ of
label: BODY

text: data without going further into developing an analytics platform. But we will need to
label: BODY

text: continue to navigate this distinction, given our recent work to bring multiple datasets
label: BODY

text: together for the HDX COVID-19 Map Explorer.
label: BODY

text: The biggest surprise was that the Humanitarian Exchange Language — which we saw
label: BODY

text: initially as a mostly independent data standard — became an integral part of HDX.
label: BODY

text: An example of Quick Charts, which uses HXL to automatically transform data
label: BODY

text: 5.4 Staying Focused
label: H4

text: The Humanitarian Exchange Language
label: BODY

text: In 2012, OCHA was looking to reduce the friction of sharing humanitarian data
label: BODY

text: among different organizations. Standard templates were impractical: each
label: BODY

text: organization already has its own tools and processes, and every crisis has different
label: BODY

text: needs. Instead, OCHA created a data exchange standard, which would become the
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian Exchange Language (HXL).
label: BODY

text: The initial version of HXL focused on the semantic web and linked data, which
label: BODY

text: were highly visible at the time because of adoption by the UK Government and
label: BODY

text: the pharmaceutical industry. However, despite some successful prototype work,
label: BODY

text: that approach failed to generate significant uptake: the semantic web required a
label: BODY

text: high level of technical expertise, rare skills, and custom software, none of which is
label: BODY

text: easily available to humanitarian organizations, especially in the field. Plus, no one
label: BODY

text: understood it and it was difficult to explain.
label: BODY

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA | SEPTEMBER 2020
label: BODY

text: 6.  HDX TODAY:
label: H4

text: KEY RESULTS
label: H4

text: In 2015, we introduced Objectives and Key Results (OKRs) as a way to organize our
label: BODY

text: work. Our team had grown to over twenty people spread across several continents.
label: BODY

text: Inspired by Google, OKRs can help teams and individuals prioritize their work and
label: BODY

text: learn from both success and failure. OKRs are both top-down and bottom-up with all
label: BODY

text: team members committing to ambitious goals that are slightly out of reach. Progress is
label: BODY

text: tracked quarterly.
label: BODY

text: We set five objectives for the HDX team in 2015 which have been mostly unchanged
label: BODY

text: since:
label: BODY

text: 1.	 Increase relevant data in HDX
label: BODY

text: 2.	 Increase field use of HDX
label: BODY

text: 3.	 Increase the number of datasets that have a corresponding visual
label: BODY

text: 4.	 Increase awareness of HDX
label: BODY

text: 5.	 Increase trust in HDX
label: BODY

text: With the grant from the HIF in 2014, we rebooted HXL and connected it to the
label: BODY

text: work being undertaken to create HDX. We assembled a working group with
label: BODY

text: members from UN agencies, NGOs, donors, and volunteer groups. Because most
label: BODY

text: humanitarian data was (and still is) managed in spreadsheets, the working group
label: BODY

text: decided to abandon the earlier approach, and simply add semantic hashtags to the
label: BODY

text: tops of spreadsheet columns, such as #affected for the number of people affected.
label: BODY

text: The inclusion of the hashtag makes it possible to merge data across spreadsheets
label: BODY

text: and to identify mistakes within a data column.
label: BODY

text: HXL 1.0 was released in mid 2014 and found several early adopters, including the
label: BODY

text: British Red Cross and UNHCR. As of July 2020, over one hundred organizations are
label: BODY

text: sharing HXL-hashtagged data on HDX.
label: BODY

text: An ALNAP case study on HXL in 2016, following up on the HIF grant, concluded
label: BODY

text: that “pilot participants expressed great confidence in the HXL hashtag solution”
label: BODY

text: and “early versions of data-cleaning, merging and data visualisation tools are
label: BODY

text: appreciated,” but also that “to ensure take-up and active use of the standard among
label: BODY

text: humanitarian workers with lower technical competence, [the HDX team] would
label: BODY

text: need to develop tools that clearly showed the benefits of HXL.”
label: BODY

text: Better Together
label: BODY

text: The decision to combine the development of HXL and HDX into a single project has
label: BODY

text: paid dividends. Data standardization has resulted in significant time savings for
label: BODY

text: the HDX team, allowing Quick Chart previews for thousands of datasets without
label: BODY

text: the need for manual design work, and a low-effort Extract-Transform-Load (ETL)
label: BODY

text: pipeline for publishing data from external providers. Quick Charts have acted as
label: BODY

text: an incentive to data providers to share even more data on HDX, creating a virtuous
label: BODY

text: circle. Several organizations have taken advantage of the HXL standard and HXL
label: BODY

text: software tools, which are all open source, to create their own HXL tooling for
label: BODY

text: internal use.
label: BODY

text: HXL still faces challenges: user research conducted separately by OCHA, the British
label: BODY

text: Red Cross, and Ushahidi has identified barriers to adoption by field users who have
label: BODY

text: little bandwidth to learn how the standard works and are hesitant to move away
label: BODY

text: from their existing data processing workflows. For now, HXL remains a core part of
label: BODY

text: the HDX infrastructure, saving data processing time and creating interoperability
label: BODY

text: behind the scenes.
label: BODY

text: Grab a spreadsheet of
label: BODY

text: humanitarian data
label: BODY

text: Insert a new row between
label: BODY

text: the headers and the data
label: BODY

text: Add some HXL hashtags
label: BODY

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA | SEPTEMBER 2020
label: BODY

text: Equally important to setting key results is having an easy way to measure them. We
label: BODY

text: initially relied on Google Analytics for analyzing user behaviour, but in 2016 began
label: BODY

text: using Mixpanel which allowed us to create more complex queries.
label: BODY

text: Mixpanel’s capability has also allowed us to add analytics data as a feature on the HDX
label: BODY

text: platform: users can explore the number of visitors and downloads of top datasets on
label: BODY

text: every organization page. Each quarter we share organization-specific analytics data
label: BODY

text: with our top contributing organizations, which has proven to be a popular form of
label: BODY

text: feedback helping them to justify their investment in data sharing to management.
label: BODY

text: There are three key quantitative metrics that the HDX team monitors closely: the
label: BODY

text: number of organizations on HDX, the number of datasets, and the number of unique
label: BODY

text: users. The charts below provide an overview of our progress for the six years from July
label: BODY

text: 2014 to July 2020.
label: BODY

text: The number of organizations
label: BODY

text: Starting with an initial 28 organizations, that number has grown to over 300
label: BODY

text: organizations as of July 2020. (An organization on HDX can be a legal entity such as
label: BODY

text: UNHCR or an informal entity such as the Accelerated Education Working Group). Our
label: BODY

text: user research has shown that one of the key determinants of how much a user trusts a
label: BODY

text: dataset is based on the organization it comes from. HDX has worked with hundreds of
label: BODY

text: organizations to help them establish a data sharing presence on HDX.
label: BODY

text: A significant ‘house cleaning’ exercise in 2018 removed organizations that had joined
label: BODY

text: the platform but had not started sharing data publicly. The reason seemed to be that an
label: BODY

text: enthusiastic staff member would create the organization but then was not able to get
label: BODY

text: the internal permissions to share data publicly. We changed our system to only show
label: BODY

text: organizations that have shared at least one dataset; other organizations can register
label: BODY

text: but remain invisible to the user until data is shared.
label: BODY

text: 6.1 Growth in HDX
label: H4

text: Organizations,
label: BODY

text: Datasets, and Users
label: BODY

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA | SEPTEMBER 2020
label: BODY

text: The number of datasets
label: BODY

text: The number of datasets available on HDX has steadily grown to over 17,000. In 2019,
label: BODY

text: efforts to automate data sharing from organizations like UNHCR and OpenStreetMap
label: BODY

text: (via the Humanitarian OpenStreetMap Team) resulted in a large number of datasets
label: BODY

text: being added, including 4,500 datasets from the World Bank. The large number of
label: BODY

text: datasets can be misleading since it depends on how the data is sliced, i.e. by indicator
label: BODY

text: or country.
label: BODY

text: It has never been our goal to simply increase the number of datasets on the platform
label: BODY

text: but rather to increase the amount of relevant data. And to ensure data about new or
label: BODY

text: existing crises continues to be added. Our research has shown that individual datasets
label: BODY

text: coming from field locations account for about 35% of the datasets on HDX, but are
label: BODY

text: downloaded significantly more than other types of data.
label: BODY

text: The number of unique visitors
label: BODY

text: HDX’s steady growth in users, from a few thousand to a peak of 200,000 per month, tells
label: BODY

text: the story of how we have steadily gained adoption and scaled the platform. Smaller
label: BODY

text: changes, spikes, and dips in the number of unique users lets us monitor the use of
label: BODY

text: HDX for new crises and understand seasonal effects on usage. The graph below shows
label: BODY

text: monthly unique users since 2014, with a significant increase in March and April 2020
label: BODY

text: due to the start of the COVID-19 pandemic.
label: BODY

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA | SEPTEMBER 2020
label: BODY

text: A North Star metric is the one measurement that is most important to a company’s
label: BODY

text: or organization’s long-term success. For HDX, our North Star metric is the number of
label: BODY

text: users from countries with ongoing humanitarian operations. We knew that for HDX to
label: BODY

text: succeed, it had to be useful to staff working in the field, since those staff are closest to
label: BODY

text: data collection efforts in humanitarian operations.
label: BODY

text: Because HDX does not track the activity of individual users by name, we cannot directly
label: BODY

text: measure usage by humanitarians. However, as a proxy for this, we monitor and work
label: BODY

text: to increase the number of users who are based in countries with active humanitarian
label: BODY

text: crises, and we maintain a higher growth target for those countries than for users overall
label: BODY

text: (35% versus 25% year-on-year growth). The list of countries included is based on those
label: BODY

text: with Humanitarian Response Plans or other types of plans (HRP+).6
label: BODY

text: The growth in users from these focus countries has outpaced growth in users overall.
label: BODY

text: From August 2016 through August 2020 (the period for which the data is available),
label: BODY

text: growth in monthly users from HRP+ countries was 943% compared to 566% across all
label: BODY

text: countries. As a percentage of total users (second graph below), the number of users
label: BODY

text: from HRP+ countries grew steadily until mid 2018, when it flattened out due to the
label: BODY

text: rapid growth in users globally. This ratio is something we will continue to work on.
label: BODY

text: 6.2 North Star Metric:
label: H4

text: Users from field
label: BODY

text: operations
label: BODY

text: 6  OCHA works with partners
label: BODY

text: to produce Humanitarian
label: BODY

text: Response Plans and other
label: BODY

text: types of plans to guide
label: BODY

text: humanitarian operations.
label: BODY

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA | SEPTEMBER 2020
label: BODY

text: Another useful indicator of field use of HDX is the popularity of the Common
label: BODY

text: Operational Datasets (CODs), which include standard subnational administrative
label: BODY

text: divisions and baseline population data for each country. Before HDX was built,
label: BODY

text: OCHA managed a catalogue of these datasets, which was migrated to HDX in 2015.
label: BODY

text: CODs account for fewer than 3% of the datasets on HDX, but they are popular. At the
label: BODY

text: beginning of 2020, 1 in 3 people who downloaded data on HDX downloaded a COD.
label: BODY

text: In the private sector, the cost per user is a way to estimate how much to charge for a
label: BODY

text: service or subscription. For non-profits, it is a way to understand the level of investment
label: BODY

text: needed over the course of the project or programme. The cost per user always starts
label: BODY

text: high with significant upfront development costs and a small number of initial users, but
label: BODY

text: that cost should go down.
label: BODY

text: The figure below illustrates that HDX’s average monthly cost per user has steadily
label: BODY

text: decreased from 2014 until now. HDX was established in 2014 with an annual cost
label: BODY

text: of approximately $2.4 million, which included $1.7 million project costs and the
label: BODY

text: remainder in OCHA staff costs.
label: BODY

text: HDX operating costs have since decreased, falling most dramatically in 2017 when
label: BODY

text: the Centre for Humanitarian Data was established. At that stage, HDX was absorbed
label: BODY

text: into the overall costs of the Centre which includes additional workstreams for data
label: BODY

text: responsibility, data literacy and predictive analytics. Staff and common costs are
label: BODY

text: shared across the Centre’s workstreams. In 2020, the Centre budgeted approximately
label: BODY

text: $1.7 million towards managing HDX.
label: BODY

text: An even bigger impact on the cost per user has been the growth of the HDX user
label: BODY

text: base. While fixed costs have been stable, the number of unique users of the platform
label: BODY

text: has grown to, on average, 100,000 per month by mid-2020. The combined effect of
label: BODY

text: decreasing costs and increasing users has led to a significant drop in the monthly cost
label: BODY

text: per user from $43.90 in 2014 to $1.30 by July 2020.
label: BODY

text: 6.3 Cost per User
label: H4

text: When HDX launched in 2014, only a handful of humanitarian organizations had
label: BODY

text: dedicated websites and systems offering access to their data. Today, dozens of
label: BODY

text: organizations do. This includes sophisticated sites such as WFP’s HungerMap and the
label: BODY

text: International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies’ GO platform. The
label: BODY

text: increased investment in these organizational platforms has helped improve the quality
label: BODY

text: and timeliness of the data shared on HDX and created a growing data ecosystem. It has
label: BODY

text: also enabled a shift in the humanitarian sector towards more evidence-based decision
label: BODY

text: making, although the dynamics of the data-to-decision-making continuum needs more
label: BODY

text: investigation.
label: BODY

text: 6.4 Connections in the
label: H4

text: Network
label: BODY

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA | SEPTEMBER 2020
label: BODY

text: In 2015, we developed a five-year vision for HDX. To be successful, we said that we
label: BODY

text: required:
label: BODY

text: •	 A sustainable, diverse, multi-skilled team of highly motivated individuals who are
label: BODY

text: geographically distributed but aligned around a common goal.
label: BODY

text: •	 An engaged community that believes in the need for HDX and wants to be part of
label: BODY

text: the process of making it succeed.
label: BODY

text: •	 A supportive policy environment that encourages trust, quality, standards, access,
label: BODY

text: sharing, and ease-of-use.
label: BODY

text: •	 Broadly adopted data standards for the interoperability (HXL) and quality
label: BODY

text: (metadata) of humanitarian data.
label: BODY

text: •	 A data exchange platform that is easy-to-use, open, scalable, and supports data
label: BODY

text: sharing throughout a global network of hosted data sources, and across the
label: BODY

text: information lifecycle.
label: BODY

text: •	 Continuous development of products and services that demonstrate the value of
label: BODY

text: shared data.
label: BODY

text: •	 Data literate practitioners, managers, leaders, and policy makers who are better
label: BODY

text: able to use data.
label: BODY

text: •	 Multi-year funding to foster confidence, capacity, and cooperation among partners.
label: BODY

text: 7.  THE ROAD AHEAD
label: H4

text: The diagram below illustrates the increasing number of organizations that have
label: BODY

text: shared data on HDX for sudden onset crises. It shows that the most recent events
label: BODY

text: have the largest number of organizations utilizing HDX to share data. For example, 16
label: BODY

text: organizations shared data during the 2014 West Africa Ebola outbreak, compared to
label: BODY

text: 43 organizations when the disease struck again, at a smaller scale, in the Democratic
label: BODY

text: Republic of the Congo in 2018.
label: BODY

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA | SEPTEMBER 2020
label: BODY

text: This list is as relevant today as it was in 2015 and we have made significant inroads
label: BODY

text: towards turning the vision into a reality. What we began to see back then was that we
label: BODY

text: need more than a data platform to advance data practices within the humanitarian
label: BODY

text: sector. We also need humanitarians with the skills to use data and data policy
label: BODY

text: frameworks to ensure we are not putting people’s lives at risk by making data available.
label: BODY

text: OCHA established the Centre for Humanitarian Data in The Hague in 2017 in order to
label: BODY

text: take on these wider issues. Although the Centre manages HDX, it was the success of
label: BODY

text: HDX that led to its creation. If HDX had not gained traction and exposed some of the
label: BODY

text: deeper challenges with data in humanitarian operations, we would not have been
label: BODY

text: able to attract investment for the ambitions inherent in creating an entity dedicated to
label: BODY

text: humanitarian data. The Netherlands Ministry of Foreign Affairs provided foundational
label: BODY

text: funding for the Centre in 2014 and renewed their commitment in 2020 for an additional
label: BODY

text: three years.
label: BODY

text: Over the coming period, we will be focused on two areas for HDX: closing data gaps and
label: BODY

text: ensuring sensitive data is managed responsibly.
label: BODY

text: Even with all of the gains our community has made with making data available, we
label: BODY

text: still face critical data gaps. This has become even more evident — with COVID-19
label: BODY

text: pandemic, which has shown that subnational data on cases and deaths, comorbidities,
label: BODY

text: vulnerabilities and gender disparities is missing in most countries with humanitarian
label: BODY

text: operations.
label: BODY

text: We have created the HDX Data Grid as a way to measure data completeness across the
label: BODY

text: humanitarian operations that we cover. The Data Grid divides the most important crisis
label: BODY

text: data into six categories: affected people; coordination and context; food security and
label: BODY

text: nutrition; geography and infrastructure; health and education; and population and
label: BODY

text: socio-economy.7 Data is included in the Grid if it is subnational, in a commonly-used
label: BODY

text: format, and up-to-date.
label: BODY

text: By mid-2020, HDX included Data Grids for 29 locations. The completeness of all Data
label: BODY

text: Grids combined was 43 percent. That is, 43 percent of relevant, comprehensive data
label: BODY

text: is available across 29 locations. If we add the data that is relevant but incomplete, the
label: BODY

text: total is 72 percent. This leaves 28 percent of categories with data that does not meet
label: BODY

text: the criteria or with no data at all. The Data Grids include an average of 20-30 datasets
label: BODY

text: per location. Over the next three years, we aim to reach 80 percent data completeness
label: BODY

text: through sustained advocacy and data sharing partnerships.
label: BODY

text: One of our most significant challenges with HDX is ensuring that sensitive or personal
label: BODY

text: data is not exposed through the platform. As the saying goes, trust is hard to gain
label: BODY

text: and easy to lose. We have made a concerted effort to maintain and build this trust by
label: BODY

text: supporting data responsibility — the safe, ethical, and effective management of data
label: BODY

text: — on HDX and within our community more broadly. We will continue to focus on this in
label: BODY

text: the coming years.
label: BODY

text: While we have never allowed the sharing of personal data on HDX, we are careful
label: BODY

text: to monitor every dataset added to the platform and flag sensitive, high-risk data to
label: BODY

text: our contributors. This is generally related to survey or needs assessment data (i.e.,
label: BODY

text: microdata), which is the most valuable data produced in a crisis. To help ensure this
label: BODY

text: data gets shared, we created HDX Connect which allows contributors to add just the
label: BODY

text: metadata with the underlying data made available upon request. We also offer to
label: BODY

text: assess the risk of re-identification of microdata through statistical disclosure control
label: BODY

text: processes.
label: BODY

text: 7.1 Closing Data Gaps
label: H4

text: 7  Learn more about the HDX
label: BODY

text: Data Grids in our report
label: BODY

text: on The State of Open
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian Data.
label: BODY

text: 7.2 Data Responsibility
label: HH2

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA | SEPTEMBER 2020
label: BODY

text: Although we may only find one dataset in several hundred with a high risk of
label: BODY

text: re-identification, we find ourselves investing more of our time and technical resources
label: BODY

text: in ensuring that this data is not exposed publicly. The HDX team will always prioritize
label: BODY

text: ensuring that no high-risk data is shared over driving growth in datasets or users.
label: BODY

text: As HDX continues to scale and mature, its development will be guided by user feedback
label: BODY

text: and our community of data contributors. While the majority of our time is now spent
label: BODY

text: on maintenance — making sure things are working as they should be — we also want
label: BODY

text: to optimize the experience in a number of ways, from quicker search results to more
label: BODY

text: automated updates to the data and improved data ‘freshness’.
label: BODY

text: In May 2020, we ran a survey at the point of data download to better understand
label: BODY

text: how people intend to use data from HDX and what type of entity they were affiliated
label: BODY

text: with. We were trying to measure the derived value of the data, rather than just access
label: BODY

text: to it. Over one thousand people — from academia, governments, international
label: BODY

text: organizations, the media, NGOs and the private sector — responded to the survey
label: BODY

text: over a two-week period. The results were as expected: people use data to do research,
label: BODY

text: perform analysis, create maps, develop reports, validate models or for a math project,
label: BODY

text: as one 14 year-old boy told us.
label: BODY

text: We also heard the following from respondents, with the type of entity they said they
label: BODY

text: work for in parentheses:
label: BODY

text: “I rely on HDX heavily for analysis.” (government)
label: BODY

text: “I always refer to HDX to search for the latest administrative and health district
label: BODY

text: boundaries.” (international organization)
label: BODY

text: “HDX is a valuable resource, fundamental for NGOs and those parties engaged in
label: BODY

text: understanding conflict.” (international NGO)
label: BODY

text: “The datasets are very effective in capturing the IDP [internally displaced people]
label: BODY

text: numbers and sites in Somalia.” (local NGO)
label: BODY

text: “The data has been very useful with understanding the amount of infrastructure
label: BODY

text: and population at risk from sea level rise and flooding.” (academia)
label: BODY

text: “Fantastic. I love it. But I would like to see more real time data.” (media)
label: BODY

text: “Long life to HDX!” (NGO)
label: BODY

text: While the survey was encouraging, it did not help us to understand how a service
label: BODY

text: like HDX and the products it supports leads to better decisions or moves us beyond
label: BODY

text: efficiency and into a more effective humanitarian system. We know that better data is
label: BODY

text: needed but it is not sufficient. We also need to look at how data is used. This is where
label: BODY

text: the next set of humanitarian innovations can come in, moving beyond platforms and
label: BODY

text: tools for data collection and sharing to machine learning and predictive modeling, an
label: BODY

text: area that the Centre for Humanitarian Data is exploring.
label: BODY

text: Nevertheless, even as donor interest shifts to exciting new areas, it is critical that HDX
label: BODY

text: and our data peers remain resourced. While we believe that predictive analytics has the
label: BODY

text: potential to improve how response happens, models can only work based on good data
label: BODY

text: used by skilled staff in an ethical way: they stand on the shoulders of services like HDX.
label: BODY

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA | SEPTEMBER 2020
label: BODY

text: 7.3 “Long Life to HDX!”
label: BODY
